title: Clean-up operation after poppy wreaths found burned
text:
A clean-up operation has taken place in Neath after eight poppy wreaths were found burned at a war memorial.
The charred wreaths were discovered at the town's Memorial Gate.
I was absolutely appalled; disgusted. It's sickening to think that people can do this - to people that gave their lives for our lives.
– Jeff Coleman, Chairman, Royal British Legion in Neath Local residents have condemned the act of vandalism. Credit: ITV News Today members of the Royal British Legion, along with people in the local community, cleared the area and put down new wreaths.
A small service of remembrance was also held.
Whoever is responsible should be absolutely ashamed of themselves. Obviously they must learn what [the wreaths] meant, and what they mean to the public, and what they mean to families and the people who've given their lives.
– Cllr Peter Rees, deputy leader, Neath Port Talbot County Borough Council The wreaths are laid annually as a symbol of commemoration to those who fought and lost their lives during world wars and recent conflicts.
The act of vandalism has caused much upset in the local community and police are still investigating.
Sergeant Chris Mackay, of South Wales Police, described it as a "particularly offensive" act.
